Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Electroacupuncture for Nonspecific Low Back Pain

Participants.evidence: Participants with nonspecific low back pain were included, with no specific setting mentioned.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention was electroacupuncture, compared to standard therapy or manual needling therapies.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to assess the efficacy of electroacupuncture compared to standard therapy and manual needling therapy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain intensity, measured using the Visual Analog Scale and Numerical Rating Scale at treatment completion and follow-up.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ten studies with 660 participants were included

Result_Outcome.evidence: Electroacupuncture with standard therapy showed a significant reduction in pain compared to standard therapy alone (SMD -0.83, 95% CI -1.22 to -0.43, P < 0.0001).
